song.title: Just Sing!
song.author: Mark and Helen Johnson
song.summary: A firm favourite in schools across the land. A defining ‘statement song’, which unashamedly waves the banner for singing in schools everywhere. Beware, you may find yourself singing some very unlikely lyrics, but you’ll have great fun doing it!
song.teachingTips:
• This song will work very well with two groups, each singing alternate phrases and everyone singing the chorus and the phrase ‘just sing!’
  • Make sure you attack the syncopated rhythms with energy. Try standing to sing the song and get the children to change position every time they sing the word ‘sing’.
  • In the chorus, before attempting to sing, get the children to clap the rhythm and say the words out loud in time. Then introduce the melody.

phrases.content: <large>Don’t you worry </large>if it’s heard or not,
Keep on singing, <large>give it all you’ve got,</large>
<large>Don’t you worry </large>if it’s heard or not,
Keep on singing, <large>give it all you’ve got,</large>
<large>Don’t you worry </large>if it’s heard or not,
Keep on singing, <large>give it all you’ve got,</large>
<large>Don’t you worry </large>if it’s heard or not,
Keep on singing, <large>give it all you’ve got,</large>

resources.title: Writing New Lyrics
resources.content:
[{"key":"82c73aea342f49e9","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"
  • To recognize recurring rhythm and rhyme patterns in lyrics
  • To compose lyrics within a given rhythmic and rhyming scheme
","title":"What’s achievable","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/green-star-1614702483w2iKm.png"}},{"key":"a43b5d2d5d8eea9c","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

White/blackboard; Just Sing! instrumental track

","title":"What you need","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/blue-wrench-16147025258WedI.png"}},{"key":"980850b5e1bd2563","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Draw attention to the language in the last line of each verse (e.g. Humpty Dumpty/kangaroo; mashed potato/vindaloo). Observe the recurring rhythm/rhyme pattern. There are four syllables in the first phrase (Hump-ty-Dump-ty) and three in the second (kan-ga-roo). Also, the second word or phrase always ends with an ‘oo’ rhyme. Write some new ‘last lines’ and try them out:

'Sing… (4 syllables), sing… (3 syllables/oo rhyme), just sing!’

Think about using words that are fun to sing – ones that make your tongue and lips move a lot or ones that make you smile. Which of your new lyrics are the most enjoyable to sing? Why?

Sing the song through with all your new lyrics!

","title":"","noMargin":false,"background_color":null}},{"key":"2f05cfff030cec2b","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Very often we teach songs without talking about the content. Take some time to discuss the children’s experience of singing. When do they sing? Where do they sing? Why? What about other people in their family? Do they have any concept of the benefits of singing?

","title":"Branch Out","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/u1874-1614695090s5QJx.png"}}]
resources.summary: Have fun composing some new lyrics for Just Sing! using recurring syllabic rhythm/rhyme patterns. Your lips and tongue will be buzzing with all the fabulously ‘chewable’ words you could choose.

resources.title: SINGING
resources.content:
[{"key":"2a82cf520889447b","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Singing is good for you! What other single activity do you know of that has the capacity to:

  • improve lung-capacity and circulation
  • improve posture, confidence and self-esteem
  • enhance mental alertness and creativity
  • reduce blood pressure and anxiety
  • boost the immune system
  • release pain-relieving endorphins and muscle tension
  • exercise all the major muscle groups in the upper body
  • improve your mood at the same time (by releasing the same ‘feel-good’ endorphins as chocolate)?

All with no cost or calories! This singing stuff is good!

","title":"","noMargin":false,"background_color":null}}]

resources.title: Singing Body Map
resources.content:
[{"key":"e85b93839303be1a","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Study the health benefits of singing by drawing a map of the body illustrating the following areas:

  • The physical act of singing releases endorphins – the brain’s ‘feel good’ chemicals
  • Group-singing creates a sense of belonging and connection
  • Singing exercises core muscles and encourages oxygen intake, which leads to increased alertness
  • Singing is a natural stress-reducer
  • Singing even improves neurological functioning
","title":"","noMargin":false}}]

songs.title: I Have A Song To Sing

resources.title: Doodle Video
resources.content:
[{"key":"30e6bd6a3ce70f8c","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Make a ‘Doodle video’<\/strong> using video software like Windows Movie Maker or Apple VideoPad for Macs. Choose a song to learn as a class. Number each line of the song then put the number and the lyric line on the back of pieces of A4 paper. Get children to draw a picture showing the meaning of the song line in pairs and when finished, take photos of each picture to create the class Doodle video!<\/p>\n","title":"","noMargin":false}}]

resources.title: Where Do You Sing?
resources.content:
[{"key":"10c67c7aaf925901","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Conduct a class\/school survey, to find out when or where people sing most (include school staff as well), e.g. I sing most in the… kitchen\/bath\/car\/school; when I’m happy\/sad\/excited etc.<\/p>\n","title":"","noMargin":false}}]

resources.title: Show Time
resources.content:
[{"key":"c96c1252a8cd9212","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Ideal for 2 sessions

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"adb63e8cc28d84a3","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"
  • To prepare songs for performance
  • To follow simple performance directions
  • To suggest ways to improve a performance
","title":"What’s achievable","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/green-star-1614702483w2iKm.png"}},{"key":"5a2b814e511bfe25","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Performance space; an audience!

","title":"What you need","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/blue-wrench-16147025258WedI.png"}},{"key":"4d9f0207dabba953","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Perform; audience; loud; strong; quiet; getting louder; getting quieter; smooth; spiky; solo; group

","title":"Key vocabulary","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/icons-keyvocab-280x280-27-1620218359Ng3ET.png"}},{"key":"aae118bcde4212ac","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Remind children of the songs they have enjoyed singing over the past term. Which songs did they like best? Ask the class to share their favourites and give reasons for their choices. Perhaps they liked the lyrics, the catchy tune in the chorus, or how the song made them feel.

Children could create a list of their favourite songs. Use their answers to compile a class ‘Top Ten’.

Next, choose one or two class favourites and provide an opportunity to perform them to an audience, e.g. different classes or parents. Perhaps they could perform in an assembly, at a school event or in the playground at the end of break time.

As you plan a performance, discuss some of the following with the class:

  • What shall we sing? Choose a song! Make sure everyone knows it well and understands what it is about.
  • Who shall sing? Try varying the texture of the song by introducing a solo line or two. You could also decide which parts of the song could be sung by a small group or the whole class.
  • How shall we sing? Use simple dynamics to add interest. Which parts of the song could be sung softly, loudly etc.? Think about articulation: are there any words that need to be emphasized or sung in a certain way (e.g. smooth or spiky)?
  • Where? If possible, practise in the performance space and think about how the class will be positioned.

Other things!

You might also like to think about using instruments to accompany the song or creating simple actions to bring the song to life.

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"bf0ee10a793ceacd","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Following the performance, ask the class to share their thoughts about the experience. How did they feel? Which parts of the performance went well? Did the performance feel different to the rehearsal?

Are there any things they might improve or change if they were to perform again?

If possible, you could try creating a recording or film of the performance to share with the class.

","title":"Step It Up!","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/u1873-1614695091mFFrP.png"}},{"key":"b6e8403f132dc245","layout":"title-block","attributes":{"title":"ASSESSMENT SUGGESTIONS","background_color":"#009CCF"}},{"key":"3d3f0e6026792547","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"
  • Can they show an awareness of different roles in music performance, e.g. performer, audience?
  • Can they prepare a song for performance, suggesting simple ways to enhance the performance (e.g. actions, facial expression, simple dynamics)?
  • Can they talk about their performances (e.g. talking about things they enjoyed or that went well)?
  • Can they follow simple direction (e.g. following actions)?
","title":"","noMargin":false}}]

songs.title: Come With Me To The Beach

resources.title: Lyrics
resources.content:
[{"key":"74b94e0004299ae7","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Ideal for 2 sessions

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"bdeb125a8344630d","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"
  • To recognize recurring rhythm and rhyme patterns in lyrics
  • To compose lyrics within a given rhythmic and rhyming scheme
  • To prepare a song for performance
","title":"What’s achievable","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/green-star-1614702483w2iKm.png"}},{"key":"7c15d098a37094a8","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Syllable; phrase; chorus; melody; rhythm; scan

","title":"Key vocabulary","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/icons-keyvocab-280x280-27-1620218359Ng3ET.png"}},{"key":"4956699c7d92e7c1","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Just Sing! is a great song for performance.

This song will work very well with two groups each singing alternate phrases and everyone singing the chorus and the phrase 'Just Sing!' Get to know the song and make sure the class attacks the syncopated rhythms with energy. Try standing to sing the song and get the children to change position every time they sing the word 'sing'.

In the chorus, before attempting to sing, get the children to clap the rhythm and say the words out loud, in time. Then, introduce the melody.

Once the class knows the song well, try writing some additional lyrics.

Draw attention to the language in the fifth and sixth lines of each verse (e.g. 'Humpty Dumpty' / 'Kangaroo'; 'Mashed potato' / 'Vindaloo').

Observe the recurring rhythm/rhyme pattern. There are four syllables in the first phrase (Hump-ty Dump-ty) and three in the second (Kan-gar-oo). Also, the second word or phrase always ends in an 'oo' rhyme.

Write some new last lines and try them out:

  • Sing... (4 syllables) 
  • Sing... (3 syllables / 'oo' rhyme) 
  • Just sing!

Think about using words that are fun to sing, ones that make your tongue and lips move a lot, or ones that make you smile. Which of your new lyrics are the most enjoyable to sing? Why?

Sing the song through with all your new lyrics! Practise singing the class verse to the instrumental track. Do the new lyrics scan well? Is there anything that could be improved? Take the children's suggestions and make changes as necessary. Once the children know the song well, arrange for them to perform it to another class or in a school assembly.

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"11a2b7dfd2adccc9","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Divide the class into five groups and assign each a verse from the song. Challenge the groups to write additional lyrics for the fifth and sixth lines and to practise the verse for performance. 

Give each group some time to rehearse and then bring everyone together to perform the song.

","title":"Step It Up!","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/u1873-1614695091mFFrP.png"}},{"key":"e5ccf68fa06380f3","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Very often we teach songs without talking about the content. Take some time to discuss the children's experience of singing. When do they sing? Where do they sing? Why? What about other people in their family?

Talk to the class about the benefits of singing:

  • Singing makes you happy! It lowers cortisol and produces oxytocin, which relieves stress and tension. It also boosts confidence through the release of endorphins
  • Singing is a mindful activity, allowing us to live in the moment
  • Singing together creates a strong sense of community and togetherness
  • Singing can help us express our emotions
  • Singing improves breathing and strengthens the immune system

Ask the class to create a poster to promote singing, using ideas generated from the discussion. Display them in different parts of the school or on the school website. Or, how about performing a song in an assembly or in the playground and sharing the posters they have created?

","title":"Branch Out","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/u1874-1614695090s5QJx.png"}},{"key":"631866b1330d4487","layout":"title-block","attributes":{"title":"ASSESSMENT SUGGESTIONS","background_color":"#009CCF"}},{"key":"464154fb4a5febb2","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"
  • Can they compose lyrics following a rhythmic and rhyming structure?
  • Can they identify the structure of a song?
  • Can they comment on their work, identifying aspects that could be improved?
","title":"","noMargin":false}}]

resources.title: In Harmony
resources.content:
[{"key":"ca8a6740d7783e7d","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Ideal for 1-2 sessions

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"9d083ee0f403b992","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"
  • To perform a simple harmony
  • To maintain a part in an ensemble
","title":"What’s achievable","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/green-star-1614702483w2iKm.png"}},{"key":"faf793a50b5be717","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Tuned percussion (A B G A F E)

","title":"What you need","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/blue-wrench-16147025258WedI.png"}},{"key":"ecf1f0728c31025a","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Tempo; pulse; listen; verse; chorus; melody; harmony; two parts; duet; ensemble; soprano; alto; tenor; bass

","title":"Key vocabulary","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/icons-keyvocab-280x280-27-1620218359Ng3ET.png"}},{"key":"1f4753153743b2b5","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

To get the class used to the idea of performing in two parts, try this simple rhythm warm-up:

Perform some actions together (e.g. stretch arms, clap hands, stamp) to a steady count of ‘1 2 3 4’.

Next, divide the class into two groups and assign an action to each. Repeat the actions over and over, making sure the tempo remains steady, e.g.

  • Group 1: Stretch arms in a rainbow motion (for four beats or counts)
  • Group 2: Clap hands (for four beats or counts)

Can the class perform their actions at the same time, maintaining a steady pulse? Next, introduce a signal to swap actions, such as a tambourine shake or by saying ‘switch’. Can each group maintain their part and keep the tempo steady?

Music Matters is a great song for getting the class to sing in two groups and in the last two verses, the chorus is sung alongside the verses. Each verse and chorus repeats, so begin by dividing the class into two groups as before and take it in turns to sing the melody to each other. Is everyone singing in tune? Is the rhythm accurate?

Next, focus on the last two verses of the song, where the chorus is sung alongside the verses. Assign the verse to Group 1 and the chorus to Group 2. Try singing the parts together. Remember, you can also select the Group 2 vocal track to help everyone practise their individual part.

Add a tuned percussion part:

Try adding some percussion to the song. The long, slow notes of the chorus when ‘Music matters’ is being sung can be played on tuned percussion, either the melody – A B G A – or, more simply, the harmony notes – F G E F.

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"c2c74fe32a14ebac","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Explain to the class that music can be written in parts. Sometimes, all the musicians play or sing the same thing, or different groups or individuals will play different parts which fit together to create harmony.

An ensemble such as a choir might all sing in unison, meaning all the singers sing the same melody line. Or the choir might be divided into two or more parts, often dependent on the types of voices.

Listen to the Hallelujah Chorus from Messiah by Handel. This piece was written for a large chorus of singers divided into four sections according to their voice type (Soprano, Alto, Tenor and Bass).

","title":"Listen","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/listen-01-1615991956LRT6z.png"}},{"key":"891d8b908b7a62e3","layout":"video","attributes":{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IUZEtVbJT5c","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"aabb8a8d41956b8d","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"

Or how about listening to the Barcarolle from The Tales of Hoffmann by Offenbach and see if the class can identify where the two soloists are singing individually, together or two separate parts. Can they also listen out for when they are accompanied by a choir?

","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"6598431c1887b8c2","layout":"video","attributes":{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0u0M4CMq7uI","title":"","noMargin":false}},{"key":"78d1565e8b742166","layout":"icon-bullet","attributes":{"body":"

Music Matters and Just Sing! highlight the importance of music and singing specifically. Take some time to discuss the children’s experience of singing. When do they sing? Where do they sing? Why? What about other people in their family? Do they have any concept of the benefits of singing? Ask the class to carry out some research at home, asking members of their family and close friends about their ideas and feelings about music and singing.

","title":"Branch Out","noMargin":false,"image":"https://assets.sparkyard.com/uploads/icons/u1874-1614695090s5QJx.png"}},{"key":"9b18a96ec878c7b6","layout":"title-block","attributes":{"title":"Assessment Suggestions","background_color":"#009CCF"}},{"key":"ea377d777dd0df77","layout":"wysiwyg","attributes":{"body":"
  • Can they sing a simple song in two parts?
  • Can they maintain a simple harmony part?
  • Can they develop an understanding of how music can be written in different parts and voices (e.g. SATB choir, solos, duets)?
","title":"","noMargin":false}}]
